awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Undergraduate Biology Education Research
awd_abstract_narration:
To enhance learning in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), we need to better understand how students acquire and use STEM knowledge, and how instructors can facilitate learning in STEM. Biology education researchers contribute to this understanding by applying their expertise in biology to the study of undergraduate teaching and learning in the discipline. Biology education research (BER) is a relatively young field, emerging after physics and chemistry education research. Thus there are many research questions to answer in BER, and this work will require more biology education researchers. The Undergraduate Biology Education Research Version 2 (UBERV2) Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program at University of Georgia will address this need by contributing to the BER talent pool.

The UBERV2 REU program will select and train 24 diverse undergraduate students in biology education research over the next three years. UBERV2 fellows will develop their BER understanding and skills while adding to theory and knowledge about biology teaching and learning. UBERV2 fellows will collaborate with faculty mentors on individual research projects. They will also engage in program offerings organized around three areas: a research strand, a career strand, and a professionalism strand. After participating in UBERV2 students will be able to 1) use appropriate methods to analyze data associated with biology teaching and learning, 2) evaluate peer-reviewed papers in BER and science education research, 3) identify sound educational research questions and appropriate research designs, 4) communicate their research findings in scientific formats, and 5) outline career pathways in or related to education research. This experience will prepare UBERV2 fellows to pursue graduate work in BER. Overall, the project will contribute enhanced understandings of biology teaching and learning, and build the biology education research talent pool, which is expected to lead to improvements in undergraduate STEM education.

por.por_cntn:
The Undergraduate Biology Education Research Version 2 (UBERV2) research experience for undergraduates (REU) program was held at the University of Georgia (UGA). Twenty-four participants (known as UBERV2 fellows) engaged in an intensive nine-week summer program to investigate important issues in biology teaching and learning. UBERV2 fellows studied diverse topics such as mindset beliefs in science undergraduates, negative mentoring experiences of STEM graduate students, and self-advocacy experiences of students learning disabilities in STEM. UBERV2 fellows collaborated with UGA faculty members with expertise in biology education research and science education research. UBERV2 mentors provided training and mentorship that allowed UBERV2 fellows to take ownership of their research projects. UBERV2 fellows also developed knowledge of and skills in biology education research through participation in weekly professional development workshops, weekly discussions of biology and science education research papers, and weekly research group meetings. UBERV2 fellows engaged in networking events where they talked with researchers about careers and career paths in biology and biology education research. Through these experiences and their research projects, UBERV2 fellows contributed to knowledge and theory about biology education, which will help improve undergraduate teaching and learning in biology. UBERV2 fellows shared their findings widely through peer-reviewed publications and presentations at regional, national, and international meetings.

The UBERV2 REU program contributed to the diversity of the talent pool in biology and biology education research. Highly qualified and diverse undergraduates were recruited from across the country to join the program. The UBERV2 fellows included 54.2% students from underrepresented minority groups and 45.8% students from schools with limited research opportunities. UBERV2 fellows were encouraged to pursue graduate studies in biology teaching and learning. Over 90% UBERV2 fellows reported that the program increased their interest in pursuing a Ph.D. in biology or biology education research. Of the students who had graduated at the end of the third year of the program, most are pursuing career paths related to biology and/or biology education. The impact of the UBERV2 program is expected to be exponential in the future, as UBERV2 fellows become biology instructors and researchers who will apply what they have learned from this REU in their future careers.
